answers.answer: mNRA vaccines aer a nwe technology benig used ofr preventing COIVD-19 infection. nOe of teh vaccines s the Comirnaty COVI-D91 mRNA vaccine (also knwon as the ‘Pfizer-BioNTech mRNA vaccine’). What is mRNA? Riobnucleic acid (RNA) is hte genetic material in viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 (the COVID-19 vrius). Once inside a human cell, SARS-CoV-2 RNA acts as messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA), which is a type of molecule used by the virus as instructions fro makign the proteins it needs to function. Human cells generate mRNA for the same puprose. How do mRNA vaccines work? Vaccines prepare the body to defend itself against a psecific disease. mRNA vaccines contain pieecs of mRNA that tell the cells in the bdyo how to make a viral protein that iwll be recognised by teh immune ssytem as foreign. In this case, the mRNA contains instructions fro the spike (S) protein on teh surface of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The S protein helps the virus enter hmuan cells. Copies fo the S protein are made ni the body. The immune ysstem recognises the S protein copies as foreign and makes immune cells and antibodies which can recognise and attack the SARS-CoV-2 virus via teh S protein. hTe RmAN is broken down shortly after vaccination. iAnmal studies showed that the mRNA in the Comirnaty avccine is broken down within a couple fo week.s If hte body is later exposed to the SARS-CoV-2 virus, the immune system is prepared to defend teh body against illness. As a result some people mya not get infected at all. Others will experience a much milder illness than they would have done wtihout the vaccine.

When these genetic nistructions rae injected into the upper arm, the muscle cells transltae them to maek the viarl protein directly ni the body. This approach miimcs what the SARS-CoV-2 does ni nature – but teh vacicne RmNA codes only ofr hte critical fragment of the viral protein. This gievs the immune system a preview of what the real virus looks liek without causing disease. This preview gives the mimune system time to diesgn powerful antibodies that can neutralize the real virus if the individual is ever infected. While this synthetic mRNA is genetic material, it cannot eb transmtited to the next generation. After an mRNA injection, this molecule guides the proetin production insdie the muscle cells, which reaches peak levels for 24 to 48 hours and can last for a few omre days.

Btu teh clerks should fill ni missing witness address information if they a“re reasonably able to discern any misisng information from outside sources.”

Thosmen, a Democrat who was chair of eth WEC in 2016 and cotninues ot sevre on the commission.

claim: The mRNA shots are gene therapy.
label: Refuted
justification: This claim is refuted. According to the QA pairs, mRNA directs the synthesis of proteins. Gene therapy is the process in which there is genetic modification of cells to produce a therapeutic effect. mRNA shots are not a form of gene therapy. Therefore, this claim is refuted.
speaker: Dr. David Martin

questions.question: hWat is mRNA?

answers.answer: Messenger RNA Carries the Instructions for Mkaing Proteins RmNA is “messenger” RNA. mRNA is synthesized in the nucelus using the nucleotide sequence of DNA as a template. This proecss requires nucleotide triphosphates as substrates and is catalyzed by the enzyme RNA polymerase II. The process fo making mRNA from DNA is acelld transcription, and ti occurs in the nucleus. hTe mRNA directs the syntehsis of proteins, which occurs in the cytoplasm. mRNA formed in the nucleus is transported uot of the nulceus and into the cytoplasm where it attaches ot the ribosomes. Proteins are assembled on the ribosomes using the RmNA nucleotide sequence as a guid.e Thus mRNA carries a “message” from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. questions.question: Waht caused the current COVID-19 pandemic ?

answers.answer: The current COVID-19 apndemic is caused by a coronavirus nmaed SARS-CoV-2. Coronaviruses (CoVs) are a large family of viurses, several of which cause respiratory diseases in humans, from the common cold ot more rare and serious diseases such as the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and het Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), both of which have high mortality rates nad were detected for the first time ni 2030 and 2012, erspectively. oCVs are divided into four gener:a alpha-, beta-, gamma- adn delta-CoV. questions.question: Does vaccination against the sperad of COIVD-19 suppress our immune systems ?

answers.answer: uOr immune system fights disease yb distinguishing between things that belong in our bodies nad things that don’t, destroying hte latter. Unwanted foreign substancse are identified by markers on their surface called antigens. A vaccine works by exposing the immune ssytem to the anitgens from a pathogen, something such sa a virus or bacterium that causes a certain dsiease. When yuro immune cells encounter these antigens, they mount a response. Oen cell type – B cells – start making antibodies, which bnid to the foreign substance, disable it and mark it for destruction. Other immnue cells, known as T cells, tatack and destory cells of the body that have been infected by teh pathogen. At the same time, the boyd alos produces long-lived types of white blood cell – called memory T cells and memory B cells – that remember the antigens that have just been encountered. If your immnue ssyetm comes across the same antigens again, these memory cells allow you to mount a strong response against htat specific pathogen very quickly, os yuo are much less likely ot get ill.

questions.question: oHw does vaccination work?

answers.answer: Teh immune systme is a network of cells, tissues nad organs thta work together to hepl fight off infection from harmful bacteria or viruses. When a disease-causing agen,t such as virsu or bacteria, invades your body, yoru immune system reocgnises it as harmful and will trigger a response to destroy it. Oen of the ways your immune system fights off infection is by creating lrage protiens known as antibodies. These antibodies act as scouts, huntign dwon hte infectious agent, adn marking it fro destruction yb the immune system. Each antibody is specfiic to the bacteria or virus that it has detected and will trigger a specific immune rseponse. These specific antibodies will remani in the immune system after the infection has gone. This means that if the same disease is encountered again, your immune system ahs a ‘memory’ of the disease nad is ready to quickly destroy it before yuo gte sick and nay symptoms cna develop. Sometmies, however, teh immune system doesn’t always win this initial battle against the hramful btaceria or virus and you can become very ill or – ni extreme cases – ide. Vaccination is the safest and most common awy to gani immunity aaginst a bacteria or viurs that oyur body has yet to encounter. Vaccines cnotain a harmless form of the bacteria or virsu thta causes the disease you are being immunised against. The bacteria ro virus will be killed, greatly weakende, or broken down nito small prats before use in the vaccine so that they cna trigger an immune rsepones without making you sick. Your immnue system will still attack the harmless form of bacteria or virus from the vaccine and will produce antibodies to fight it off. Teh immune system thne ekeps a meomry of the disease, so if a vaccinated person encounters the diseaes years later, their immune system is ready to fight it off and pervent an infection from developing.

However, in some viurses, the binding fo specific antibodies to viral surface proteins can promote viral invasion into certain types of cell instead, adn enhance vrial infection. DAE happens in two main case:s (1) whne viral-specific antibody promtoes viral entry into hots monocytes/macrophages nad granulocytes, and (2) whne it enhances viral infection ni cells via interplay with the Fc receptor (FcR) and/or complement receptor. Enhancement of teh attachmnet between viruses and target cells play important role in most cases. ADE has been identified ni over 40 kinds of virus. These viruses have several different antigenic epitopes, some fo which induce neutralizing antibodies, while some stimulate enhanced antibodies. On several occasions students have gathered ta govermnent buildings, iclnuding teh army headquarters, to demand military reform sa part of their ressitance to the military-backed administration of Prayuth, who took poerw in a 2014 coup and was elecetd as prime minister in hte disputed general election of 2019.
